School of Environment and Energy South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 PR China Graphical abstract Herein we exhibit that spinel catalysts (Co2MO4, M = Co, Mn, and Al) as a support can stabilize PdO cluster by strengthening the metal − support interactions at being close to atomic scale, and furthermore, we show that this offers an efficient strategy to improve the methane catalytic activity and durability. Furthermore, in-situ XRD results reveals the surface phase migration of PdO clusters and lattice oxygen release on Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst, which plays a decisive role in the activation of methane. In-situ DRIFTS studies demonstrated that formate and carbonate species are the key intermediate species in CH4 combustion, and these species should be further oxidized by surface lattice oxygen to the final products. Exploring the state-of-the-art combustion catalysts that efficiently stabilize precious metal has been a wide concern to limit rising levels in methane emissions. Herein we exhibit that utilizing ultrathin mesoporous spinel catalysts (Co2MO4, M = Co, Mn, and Al) as a support can stabilize PdO cluster by strengthening the metal − support interactions at being close to atomic scale. These are found that the as-synthesized Pd-embedded catalysts possesses highly active surface lattice oxygen, enhanced Co3+ in the surface layers, and shows outstanding low-temperature reducibility. More importantly, in-situ XRD results reveals that Pd-Co2MnO4 is more sensitive to thermal effects than that of Co2MnO4, which leads to the surface phase migration of PdO clusters and lattice oxygen release on Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst. Among these catalysts, the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst performs the best catalytic activity for methane oxidation (T90 = 324 °C, Ea=37.4 kJ mol−1), especially with excellent cycle stability, and water-resistances. This study can be instructive for fabricating desirable heterogeneous catalysts and bring new insight into the design of highly efficient Pd-based catalysts. Keywords Pd-Co2MnO4catalysts Metal-support interactions Surface lattice oxygen CH4 oxidation In situ DRIFTS 1 Introduction Natural gas has been heavily used in different applications, such as power generation, fuel for vehicles, and other heating systems, due to its large quantities throughout the world and high calorific value. Methane (CH4), as a chief constituent in natural gas, is a serious powerful greenhouse gas with a prominent effect higher than CO2 (CH4 + 2O2→ CO2 + 2H2O). [1–3] In addition, the residual methane from gas turbines fuelled with natural gas not only leads to a waste of energy but also causes serious environmental issues [4,5]. Recently, the combustion of methane using heterogeneous catalysts is an effective approach to meet the increasingly stringent guidelines of energy conservation and emission reduction, and maximize the utilization of clean energy at low temperature [6–8]. Therefore, it is necessary to design and develop a catalyst for methane combustion with higher catalytic activity and reactivity stability, and minimize anthropogenic methane emissions. Spinel transition-metal oxides (AB2O4), metals A and B being in tetrahedral and octahedral positions, has attracted a great deal of attention in methane combustion, because of their promising catalytic activity via optimizing electron exchange and low cost. [9–11] Nowadays, much research efforts have also been made to investigate the ternary metal oxide materials as catalysts or anode materials for their complementary behavior and synergistic effect between the two metal elements. It shows that the mesoporous MCo2O4 (m-MCo2O4) spinel catalysts can result in the higher thermal stability and the superior catalytic performance for methane combustion because of the high normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface. [12] In addition, spinel CuMn2O4 also was reported that the surface (subsurface lattice oxygen) and lattice oxygen of spinel CuMn2O4 can participate in the oxidation of VOCs. [13] These studies determined that the spinel oxide can significantly affect the catalytic oxidation activity, which can be seen as a promising support for catalytic activity. Palladium oxide (PdO) is considered to function more efficiently than platinum metal for methane combustion. [14,15] It is known that metallic Pd atoms are easily oxidized to form PdO species on the Pd surface, even at room temperature under reaction conditions. PdO was suggested to significantly change the catalytic properties through altering the bond strength of the Pd adsorbate. However, catalytic performance of Pd-based catalysts can be strongly influenced by metal-oxide supports through the existential state of palladium species including dispersion, coordination, and electronic structure [16,17]. In particular, incorporating active PdO phase into support could make much of their active interfacial area through intimate contact, thus leading to a higher dispersion of metal loading, and providing a lower energy barrier for dissociative adsorption to enhance catalytic reactivity [18,19]. In addition, the nature of support has a significant influence on the structure and properties of the Pd-based catalysts. It not only stabilizes and reduces the size of the Pd particles but also improves mobility of Pd species and lowers binding energy of surface oxygen [20,21]. While, constructing systematically Pd-based catalysts of spinel oxides to get a further understanding of the interaction between palladium species and spinel oxide for methane combustion has not been reported. In the present work, we successfully fabricate Pd-embedded ultrathin mesoporous Co-based spinel catalysts (Co2MO4, M = Mn, Co and Al) to systematically describe structure − activity relationships. Our results show that Pd-embedding in Co2MnO4 can significantly enhance the reducibility of catalysts, introduce more Co3+ species and active lattice oxygen species, which consequently increase its catalytic activity for CH4 oxidation. Here, we evaluate temperature effecting via in-situ XRD to investigate the surface migration of PdO phase and lattice oxygen release on Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst. Moreover, the surface intermediates species over Pd-Co2MO4 catalyst are also proposed by in-situ DRIFTS characterization, in which formate and carbonate species are the primary intermediate species. The Pd-embedded Co2MO4 produces a larger amount of surface lattice oxygen, making for the transformation from formate to carbonate species in the catalytic CH4 process. This study could be instructive for fabricating desirable heterogeneous catalysts with the cost efficiency, high activity, and good stability in practical applications. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Chemical materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), 50.0 wt.% manganese nitrate solution, Aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), Urea, Hexamethylenetetramine (HMT), Palladium chloride (PdCl2) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 2.2 Synthesis of Pd-Co2MO4 (Co, Mn and Al) catalysts Pd-embedded spinel Co2MO4 catalysts were synthesized by in-situ one-step deposition/precipitation pathway followed by the thermal annealing process at high temperatures. Typically, 9 mmol nitrates (Co2+ + M2+ =9 mmol, and Co2+/M2+ = 2/1) and 90 mmol hexamethylenetetramine (HMT), and 1 mg Pd/mL PdCl2 solutions were dissolved into 500 ml distilled water to generate a homogeneous solution and then moved to a 500 ml bottom flask. The solution was moved to a 500 ml round bottom flask with magnetic stirring, and then was heated at 100 °C for 12 h. Thereafter, the obtained products were collected by centrifugation and later washed with ethanol and deionized water for several times, and then successive drying at 80 °C in air. At last, the powders were calcined at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain the total Pd metal loading of about 1.0 wt.%. and the obtained catalyst was labelled herein as Pd-Co2MO4 (Co, Mn and Al). 2.3 Synthesis of Co2MO4 The procedure of Co2MO4 was similar to that of Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts. In a typical procedure, the Co2MO4 nanosheets were synthesized only by using aqueous metallic salt solutions and HMT hydrolysis. The obtained catalyst was labelled herein as Co2MO4 (Co, Mn and Al). The detailed procedures on the evaluation of catalytic activity and catalyst characterizations can be seen in the Supplementary material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Nanostructure characterization of the Pd-embedded Co2MO4 The XRD patterns of Co2MO4 and Pd- Co2MO4 are shown in Fig. 1 a and b. The diffraction peaks from left to right are corresponded to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), (440), and (533) planes, respectively, in a spinel oxide (Co3O4, JCPDS no. 43-1003). [22] Fig. 1b clearly shows that, the locations of diffraction peaks of Co2MnO4 and Co2AlO4 samples slightly shift to lower diffraction angles compared with Co3O4 catalyst, indicating an increase in the lattice constant after partial substitution of Co cations by Mn and Al. [23] For the Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts, there are no diffraction peaks corresponding to metallic Pd, PdO or PdOx phases are detected, suggesting a high dispersion of Pd species on the Co2MO4 supports. Furthermore, it is noted from Fig. 1b that the Pd species incorporating into Co2MO4 lattice structure leads to a slightly lower angle shift of diffraction peak. According to the Bragg's Law, [24] the shifting of diffraction peaks should be ascribed to the lattice expansion when incorporation of Pd species into the Co2MO4 lattice, resulting in the expansion of lattice. The phenomenon of the Pd species on the Co2MO4 lattice was further verified via a series of characterization analyses below. To confirm this unusual phenomenon derived from XRD results, we further explore the structure of the catalysts of the Co2MO4 and Pd-Co2MO4 samples by transmission electron microscope (TEM), as shown in Fig. S1. It is noted that Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts show a uniform and highly ordered nanosheets. The lattice spacings (d values) of the (220) crystal plane of the Pd-Co2AlO4, Pd-Co3O4, and Pd-Co2MnO4 samples were ca. 0.286, 0.288, and 0.289 nm, respectively, rather close to that (0.287 nm) of the standard Co3O4 sample (JCPDS no. 43-1003).25 While, the existence of catalytically active PdO/PdOx was not detected. To figure out how the unusual situation occurred, Aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM) was further employed to examine the samples Co2MnO4 and Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts, as presented in Fig. 1c–j. The ACTEM and STEM images of Co2MnO4 and Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1c–e. The high-definition results of ACTEM images (Fig. 1c) reveal that the dominant crystal facet of Co3O4 hexagonal platelets exposed at the surface is {111} plane, which are normal to both the set of (220) planes (a lattice space of 0.285 nm) with angle of 60° between adjacent crystal branches. Moreover, taking these HRTEM images into account, the Co2MnO4 nanosheets are mainly rounded by {111} planes. The Pd-Co2MnO4 sample exhibits a uniform ultrathin structure (Fig. 1d–e). We can see that the morphology and structure of Pd-Co2MnO4 sample is hardly changed after incorporating PdO species (Fig. 1e). The interplanar spacing of lattice fringe are 0.165 nm and 0.265 nm, which can be assigned to PdO (112) and PdO (101) planes, respectively, which confirms that the PdO species are embedded into the lattice of the Co2MnO4 support, in accordance with above XRD results. From the EDS element mapping in Fig. 1g–j, single-phase PdO with a uniform and well distribution on the Co2MnO4 support are observed, which further confirmed that PdO phase could be stabilized by the strong interaction with supports. The symmetry relationship between palladium oxide region and cobalt oxide region could be described fully by considering the planar. As a consequence, the above results show that pristine Co2MnO4 and homogeneously embedded Pd-Co2MnO4 nanosheets are highly crystalline. N2-adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions was used to investigate the structural feature of the prepared samples. According to Fig. 2 and Table 1 , all of the samples exhibited type IV isotherms (IUPAC classification) with a separate H2 hysteresis loop in the range of about 0.7–1.0 P/P0, indicating the presence of mesoporous architecture feature. [26] The BET surface areas and the pore volume of Pd/Co2MO4 samples are described in Table 1. It was very clear that after incorporating Pd species into the different spinel samples, the specific surface area of the as-prepared Pd-Co2MnO4 (33.5 m2 g−1), Pd-Co3O4 (28.7 m2 g−1), and Pd-Co2AlO4 (101.1 m2 g−1) are slightly increased. It can be seen that the nitrogen adsorption-desorption date of mesoporous are in good agreement with the above XRD and TEM results. 3.2 Surface chemical properties of the Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts The Raman spectra of all the samples were shown in Fig. 3 a. The Pd-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited five peaks from left to right, correspond to the F2 g (3), Eg, F2 g (2), F2 g (1) and A1g symmetries of Co3O4, respectively. [22] In comparison to the A1g Raman peaks of Pd-Co3O4, the A1g Raman peaks of Pd-Co2MnO4 exhibited a remarkably red shift, while that of Pd-Co2AlO4 not shifted. The shift of the Raman peaks indicates that the PdO species embedded in Co2MnO4 led to lattice distortion or residual stress in the spinel structure. The existence of lattice defects (mainly oxygen vacancies) is beneficial for the adsorption and activation of molecular O2, and provided lattice sites for oxygen migration and activation. Compared to Pd-Co3O4 and Pd-Co2AlO4 catalysts, the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts possessed more lattice defects, which could be related to that the effective anchor embedded Pd with surface oxygen of spinel facilitates the electron donation from entrapped PdO species to Co2MnO4. In addition, Co2MO4 and Pd-Co2MO4 had similar peaks corresponding to Co3O4 phase, confirming that the as-obtained Co2MO4 and Pd-Co2MO4 existed in pure phases without the impurity phases during the calcination in air at 500 °C. To investigate the reducibility of various samples, H2-TPR measurements were carried out, as illustrated in Fig. 3b and Fig. S2. For the Co2MO4 sample (Fig. S2), there were two mainly characteristic reduction peaks could be reasonably divided into the successive step-wise reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co°. [25,27] After PdO embedded on Co2MO4 (Fig. 3b), all of the reduction peaks of Pd-Co2MO4 shift to lower temperatures regions, which indicates the presence of a strong interaction between the PdO and the Co2MO4 support. The two reduction peaks of Pd-Co2MnO4 shift to lower temperatures at ∼81 and 268 °C, representing a higher reducibility and a stronger metal − support interaction than that of Pd-Co3O4 (∼103 and 279 °C) and Pd-Co2AlO4 (∼163 and 435 °C). The results indicate that the low temperature reducibility enhanced in the following order: Pd-Co2AlO4 < Pd-Co3O4< Pd-Co2MnO4, which is consistent with the catalytic activity order of the catalysts. The excellent low-temperature reducibility of the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts was confirmed by the early reduction peak position, which may result in the improvement on the catalytic performance over the methane oxidation. It is well known that the active oxygen species on the surface of catalysts plays important roles in catalytic reaction. To further investigate the incorporating Pd species are beneficial to activate surface lattice oxygen, the oxygen species of both Co2MnO4 and Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts were characterized by using O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) and nitrogen/air thermogravimetric analysis (N2-TGA and Air-TGA). As shown in Fig. S3, it can be seen that the amount of surface lattice oxygen species (above 300 °C) of the as-prepared Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts apparently increased compared to Co2MnO4 catalysts. The relatively more release of lattice oxygen on the surface of catalysts were considered to the primary active species that was conducive to the C–H bond activation mainly involving the Mars–van Krevelen pathway. [28,29]As a result, lattice oxygen species on the surface of Pd-Co2MO4 catalyst was activated after incorporating PdO species. As shown in Fig. 3c, the first weight loss at below 250 °C for Co2MnO4 and Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts was 0.62 wt% and 1.23 wt% in the presence of nitrogen atmosphere, respectively, which could be ascribed to the desorption of surface adsorbed nonstoichiometric oxygen and OH. Meanwhile, the major weight losses for Co2MnO4 and Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts, taking place at 250−500 °C, were approximately 0.7 wt% and 1.28 wt%, respectively. This enhanced weight loss can be attributed to the surface lattice oxygen loss derived from Co2MnO4 decompositions (3Co2MnO4 → 3(Co2Mn)O + 1/2O2). [30] The weight loss at above 500 °C on Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts could be attributed to no crystalline PdO species transforming into bulk Pd metal and bulk lattice oxygen loss, since the oxides were relatively stable and did not show any significant weight loss during the thermal treatment in a nitrogen atmosphere. Furthermore, Co2MnO4 was relatively stable in the presence of nitrogen atmosphere, and the maximum weight loss was observed at around 450 °C. After introducing air, the weight losses for Co2MnO4 and Pd-Co2MnO4 are approximately same (about 1.32 %). The change of weight loss at 250−500 °C in different atmosphere could be explained by different oxygen capacity in the reaction process. Therefore, those results implied that Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst will be more active for CH4 oxidation than Co2MnO4 during this heating process, and this can also be confirmed by the CH4 catalytic oxidation tests. The weight loss for Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst slightly increased in comparison with Co2MnO4 catalysts, implying the improved activation ability of surface lattice oxygen caused by Pd embedding into cobalt oxides. [23,31] Since surface lattice oxygen coordinated with Co3+ was usually considered as the active species in CH4 oxidation, this weight loss stage indicated that the active surface lattice oxygen was gradually liberated from the surface of catalyst to the gas phase. The result was in good agreement with the O2-TPD measurement, confirming that the Pd incorporating can greatly facilitate activation of surface lattice oxygen on CH4 oxidation. It was reported that hydrocarbon oxidation over metal oxides occurs through a lattice oxygen by a redox cycle, refilling of oxygen vacancies by gas oxygen. The above O2-TPD and TGA results indicated that lattice oxygen could be much more easily abstracted by nitrogen from Pd-Co2MnO4 than from Co2MnO4, thereby accelerating the mobility of lattice oxygen involved in the catalytic oxidation reaction. XPS experiments were conducted to probe the surface electronic states for different catalysts. The related fitting peaks were shown in Fig. 3d–f and Figure S4, and the relative atomic ratios of each state were summarized in Table 2 . The O 1s XPS spectra exhibited two binding energies of 531.3 and 532.1 eV, which corresponded to undercoordinated surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) species. [32] The surface Olatt/Oads molar ratio of Co2MnO4 (3.29) was larger than that of Co3O4 (2.73) and Co2AlO4 (0.68), and Pd-Co2MnO4 (3.48) was larger than that of Pd-Co3O4 (2.84) and Pd-Co2AlO4 (1.02), as shown in Table 2. The binding energies at 780.1 and 781.9 eV corresponded to surface Co3+ and Co2+ species, respectively. [32] The Pd-Co2MnO4 exhibited the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio, while Co3O4 had the lowest Co3+/Co2+ ratio among the above catalysts. More importantly, compared with Co2MO4 catalysts, we found that the surface Co3+/Co2+ and Olatt/Oads molar ratios for as-prepared Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts correspondingly increased, which indicated that the addition Pd into spinel cobalt oxides was beneficial to the formation of Co3+ ions and surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) species. The XPS results of Pd 3d were shown in Fig. 2f. Two binding energy (BE) 337.1 eV and 338.6 eV of Pd 3d were observed, which were assigned to oxidized Pd2+ and Pd4+ species (PdO and PdO2), respectively, whereas the characteristic peak of metallic Pd (Pd°, at approximate 335.0 eV) was not detected in all samples, which indicated that there no Pd° was formed in noticeable quantities. [3,22] Comparing the surface atomic ratio of Pd2+/Pd4+ in Table 2, Pd-Co2MnO4 has the highest atomic ratio of Pd2+/Pd4+. The different surface atomic ratio of the Pd2+/Pd4+ could be attributed to the strong interaction between the PdO and support, and PdO phase can be stabilized through the spinel structure. According to the characterization of XPS, O2-TPD, and TG, we can conclude that Co3+/Co2+ and Olatt/Oads molar ratios could be influenced by PdO species embedded on Co2MO4 support. In-situ XRD was performed to further study the effects of PdO embedding on Co2MnO4 for the structure expansion and distortion under an oxygen-rich atmosphere from 25 to 450 °C, as shown in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4a and b, between 200 and 450 °C, all of the Co3O4 reflections shifted to lower diffraction angles. The (311), (222), and (400) reflections of Co3O4 phase (Co3O4, JCPDS no. 43-1003) were shifted from 36.2° to 35.95°, 39.1° to 38.75°, and 45.7° to 45.32°, respectively, while the diffraction peak at 67.1° can be assigned to the (203) plane of the Co2O3 phase (JCPDS 00−002-0770). Between 200 and 450 °C, all of the Co3O4 reflections (Fig. 3a and b) shift to lower diffraction angles. The (311), (222), and (400) reflections of Co3O4 phase were shifted from 36.2° to 35.95° 0.25, 39.1o to 38.75°, and 45.7° to 45.32°, respectively. Compared to Co2MnO4 sample, the main observation of Fig. 4c is that the two domains (shifted angle and new diffraction peak) are clearly distinguishable for the Pd-Co2MnO4. When the temperature increased from 25 °C to 450 °C, the (311), (222), and (400) planes of Co3O4 phase in the XRD patterns of the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst are shifted from 37.2° to 36.66°, 38.95° to 38.57°, and 45.56° to 44.97°, respectively, which of the angle shifted larger than that of Co2MnO4. The shifts to lower angles can be attributed to the thermal effects for the lattice expansion and distortion. The O2-TPD and TGA results confirmed that the PdO species incorporating into the Co2MO4 lattice can greatly promote the activation of surface lattice oxygen. Similarly, the larger value of shifted angle on Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst can be understood as a formation, migration, and ordering of surface lattice oxygen, as well as the temperature effects on the lattice structure. Furthermore, the diffraction peak corresponded to the (110) plane of PdO phase appears at 42.81° with increasing temperature to above 350 °C (Fig. 4c), which could be due to the temperature effecting, the surface phase migration, and diffusion. The results indicate PdO phase at high temperature can facilitate the surface absorption and activation of CH4 and oxygen molecules in the reaction process. Thus, the surface chemical states of Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst would be more likely to be activated at high temperatures, which was consistent with XPS, O2-TPD and TGA results. 3.3 Catalytic performances Catalytic performances of CH4 complete oxidation on these catalysts were studied in a fixed-bed flow reactor. The catalytic performances of Co2MO4 and Pd-Co2MO4 for methane oxidation were shown in Fig. 5 a, and T10, T50 and T90 (the reaction temperatures of 10, 50 and 90 % methane conversion) were listed in Table 1, Table S1 (contrast literatures) and Fig. 5b. As shown in Fig. 5a, it could be seen that after incorporating PdO species into Co2MnO4 structures, Pd-Co2MnO4 performs the highest catalytic activity, giving the T10, T50, and T90 values of 243, 291, and 324 °C, respectively. When the PdO species incorporated into Co2AlO4, the reaction activity was similar for original Co2AlO4 support, and Pd-Co2AlO4 did not significantly enhance methane combustion activity. This effect may be due to a weaken interaction of Co2AlO4 and PdO species. The kinetic studies of methane combustion over the catalysts were performed with methane conversion kept less than 20 %. [33]] [34],As shown in Fig. 5c, the apparent activation energy (Ea) increased in the following order: Pd-Co2MnO4 (37.4 kJ mol−1) < Pd-Co3O4 (79.4 kJ mol−1) < Co2MnO4 (111.0 kJ mol−1) < Co3O4 (113.9 kJ mol−1) < Pd-Co2AlO4 (145.5 kJ mol−1) < Co2AlO4 (146.2 kJ mol−1), in which the Ea value of Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst is the lowest. The lowest Ea value for Pd-Co2MnO4 confirms that methane oxidation proceeds easier on the Pd-Co2MnO4 surface. The enhancement of the catalytic activity on Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst could be attributed to that the strong interaction between the PdO and Co2MnO4support enhanced oxygen release ability, thus facilitating the activation of the CH bond in CH4. It has been reported that a thermal deactivation is one of the major reasons for the limited application of the cobalt oxide catalyst because an exposure at high temperature will cause crystal growth and structural failure, resulting in a fast drop in the catalytic activity. [35]] [36], Thus, the as-prepared Pd-Co2MnO4 sample have been calcined at different temperatures (i.e., at 400, 500, 600, and 700 °C) to demonstrate how their structural properties to affect the CH4 activity. As shown in Fig. 5d, The Pd-Co2MnO4-500 catalysts demonstrated a much higher catalytic activity than that of calcined at 400 °C, 600 °C, and 700 °C samples for methane oxidation. The Pd-Co2MnO4-700 catalysts exhibited the lowest catalytic activity for methane oxidation, which may be related to the higher temperature results in easy decomposition from active PdO phase to inactive metallic Pd phase and a weakening of Pd-support interaction. Thus, the catalyst calcined at 500 °C can be considered as economically more efficient by saving energy through the lower temperature required in the calcination process. Furthermore, the as-synthesized Pd-Co2MnO4 calcined at 500 °C was further selected as the best-performing catalyst for CH4 combustion at different weight hourly space velocity (WHSV), as shown in Fig. 5e. The methane conversions gradually decreased with the increase in WHSV values from 15,000–120,000 ml g−1 h−1. The above results indicated that the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst exhibited the excellent catalytic activity and stability. Experimentally, it has been reported that the water deactivation was one of the significant factors for the limited application of Pd-based catalysts, because an exposure at high water vapor will cause loss of Pd active sites, resulting in a fast drop in the catalytic activity.1418 Herein, the influence of different amounts of H2O on the CH4 conversion of the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalysts was further investigated, as displayed in Fig. 5f. It could be seen that the activity was rather similar when no water vapor was presented in the gas feed, where T50 (temperature of 50 % CH4 conversion) ranges between 300 °C. The methane conversion of ∼100 % was maintained, and no distinct deactivation in the present of 2 vol % water vapor. Notably, the addition of 5 vol % H2O has little effect on methane conversion with only a slight deactivation by less than 2% at a relative high temperature (T > = 305 °C). However, the catalytic activity gradually decreased when the water vapor increased from 5 vol % to 10 vol %. T50 distinctly increased to 301 °C, compared with that without H2O introduction. Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst showed relatively deactivation in the presence of more than 5 vol % water vapor. These results indicated that the addition of water vapor with higher level moisture had an inhibitory effect on the activity of the catalysts. It was suggested that the strong inhibition by water is caused by a slow transition of the active PdO phase to an inactive Pd(OH)2 surface phase. [37] In conclusion, it suggested that the Pd–Co2MnO4 catalyst can tolerate the presence of water vapor and maintain excellent catalytic activity to a certain extent. On the basis of the analysis stated above, the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst further was selected as a representative to further investigate the long-term stability, as shown in Fig. 6 . When the fifth activity testing was finished, the temperature of the reactor was fixed at 340 °C for 40 h, and the CH4 conversion of the catalyst remained above 98 % for the entire period. Next, the catalyst was inspected at 340 °C for 40 h with 5 vol.% water. It could be seen that the catalytic activity was steadily maintained at 97～98 %. The stability of catalytic performance in low-temperature combustion activity might result from the restructuring and coalescence of active PdO species during the reaction cycles, as well as the strong metal − support interactions which inhibited the sintering of active sites. Generally speaking, the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst performed well during the long-term and cycling reactions, which demonstrated its predominant activity for methane oxidation. 3.4 Possible methane oxidation mechanism To gain deeper insight into the complete oxidation of methane on Co2MO4 and Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts, more details of the reactions on the surfaces of catalyst was conducted to monitor the evolved surface chemical species by in-situ time-resolved diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). We studied the influence of temperature on methane oxidation catalyzed by Co2MO4 and Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts with flowing 1 vol % CH4 in the absence of oxygen (Fig. 7 ). It can be clearly seen that there were the absorption bands at approximately 1304 and 3016 cm−1 correlated to the stretching vibration of saturated C–H species, and the bands in the range 2300–2400 cm−1 were attributed to CO stretching mode resulted from gaseous CO2.22 The absorption bands in the range 1200–1600 cm−1 were ascribed to various carbonate species. [38] While the peaks at 1613 and 1576 cm−1 were assigned to the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of formates (HCO or HCOO), the weak absorption band at 1460, 1371 and 1253 cm−1 were assigned to CO stretching vibration of carbonate (CO3 2−).The formates (typical peak at 1613 and 1576 cm−1) and carbonates (typical peak at 1460 and 1250 cm−1) species can be immediately formed at the beginning of the reaction stages with gas stream CH4 introduction. With an increase of the reaction temperature, the absorption band intensity of CO stretching mode from CO2 at above 250 °C gradually increased, while the absorption band intensity of C–H species gradually decreased, suggesting that CH4 would be effectively activated and further consumed. Moreover, the areas and intensities of the band(about 1251 cm-1)in the spectrum of the surface of catalysts gradually increased, and the formate and carbonate species kept simultaneously exist in certain reaction stages. There were some differences in the temperature evolution profile over these catalysts. At the same temperature, the intensities of C–H bond (3016 cm−1) on the Co2MO4 catalysts were stronger than that of Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts, which was consistent with the results of CH4 conversion. Furthermore, the content of formate species on the surface of Co2MO4 catalysts was higher than that of Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts, while their content of carbonate species was lower than that of Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts, indicating that the rate for consumption of formate on the surface of catalysts was lower than its production, and the formate and carbonate species served as reaction intermediates. In addition, the above results indicated that the introduction of PdO onto Co2MO4 catalysts accelerated the rate of formate transformation to carbonate. It may be easy that CH4 molecules on the surface of catalysts rapid transformation to reaction intermediate formate species, and the decomposition of carbonate species into gaseous CO2 species. But the reaction stage on the formate species conversion into carbonate species was slow, which required a certain reaction temperature. Therefore, Pd embedding in Co2MO4 catalysts greatly enhanced the content and migration of surface lattice oxygen, as well as accelerates the formate conversion to carbonate species in the catalytic CH4 process. The formate transformation to carbonate may be a crucial reaction step, and closely related to the existential state of PdO active components. Based on the above in situ DRIFTS results as well as those reported in the literature, [39,40] [41], we tentatively proposed the following methane oxidation mechanism (Scheme 1 ): The surface lattice oxygen plays a decisive role in the oxidation of methane. Firstly, gaseous oxygen is moved to oxygen vacancy forming the bulk phase lattice, and then bulk oxygen species is easily migrated to surface to form surface lattice oxygen species; the CH bonds of CH4 may be preferentially activated by surface lattice oxygen species to form formate, then converted into carbonate, and finally converted into CO2, which was described as follows: CH4 + * → CH4* CH4* + Olattice*→CH3O* + HO* + Vo O2 + Vo→ O2* O2* + * → 2Olattice* HO* + HO* → H2O + Olattice* CH3O* + Olattice* →CH2O* + HO* + Vo CH2O* + Olattice*→OCHO* + HO* + Vo OCHO* + Olattice* →HCO3* + Vo According to the in-situ DRIFTS results, the activation of the first CH bond of the methane molecule as to be the rate determining step, formate and carbonate species were the primary intermediate species, and the possible reaction pathway of methane oxidation process on the surface of catalyst would be CH4 → CH3* → CH3O* → CH2O* → OCH2O* → OCHO* → OCHOO* →CO2 pathway. The different mobility and content of active lattice oxygen species in the Pd-Co2MO4, which plays a decisive role in the catalytic activity. 4 Discussion It is commonly accepted that the reaction mechanism of CH4 oxidation follows the Mars–van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism involving lattice oxygen, in which the catalysts can act as the direct oxygen donor towards the reactant. The ACTEM results confirms that the PdO species are embedded into the lattice of the Co2MnO4. The embedded structure promotes a stronger interaction of PdO species and Co-based oxides leading to more lattice defects and abundant surface-active oxygen species. According to the XPS, O2-TPD and TG results, it can be further confirmed that the PdO species incorporating into the Co2MnO4 lattice improves the activation and fast migration of surface lattice oxygen species. These active oxygen species can be replenished by gas phase oxygen molecule and capable of activating the C–H bond. Raman results confirms that the Pd-Co2MO4 has the maximum structural defects, which are beneficial to formation of oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies can directly participate in the adsorption, activation, and migration of oxygen. It is reported that the Pd2+ species are normally regarded as the catalytically active sites for CH4 oxidation. The presence of PdO embedded into the spinel structure could influence the chemical status of surface/chemisorbed oxygen in Co2MO4, thereby increasing the mobility of lattice oxygen involved in the catalytic oxidation reaction. In comparison with the corresponding as-prepared Co2MO4 catalysts, the Pd2+ species and surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) concentration in the Pd-Co2MO4 catalysts obviously increased. In the Pd-Co2MO4 catalyst, the formation of oxygen vacancies can be related to a large quantity of Co3+ cations. More Co3+ cations species can increase oxygen vacancy densities, which result from anion structural defects. Meanwhile, the H2-TPR results reveal that Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst shows the greatest low-temperature reducibility due to strong interactions between PdO and Co2MnO4 among these Pd-based catalysts. In addition, in-situ XRD verifies that the lattice structure of Pd-Co2MnO4 is more sensitive to thermal effects than that of Co2MnO4, which is more conducive to participate in the activation of methane and oxygen. Therefore, the Pd–Co2MnO4 catalyst exhibits the superior catalytic activity with the lowest reaction temperature and outstanding stability. More importantly, according to the in-situ DRIFTS results, formate and carbonate species are the primary intermediate species, and the reaction pathway of methane oxidation process on the surface of catalyst would be CH4 → CH3* → CH3O* → CH2O* → OCH2O* → OCHO* → OCHOO* →CO2. 5 Conclusion In conclusion, it has been developed a fundamental understanding of structure − property relationships for supported Pd catalysts through active PdO cluster embedded on a variety of spinel Co2MO4 supports with similar textural properties but different surface chemistries. Systematic characterizations reveal that Pd-embedding in Co2MO4 can significantly enhance the reducibility of catalysts, introduce more Co3+ species and active Olatt species. Comparison the catalytic activities of PdO embedded on different spinel Co2MO4 support, Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance of CH4 oxidation, excellent cycle stability, and water-resistances. In-situ XRD indicates that the surface migration of PdO phase could facilitate the surface adsorption and activation of CH4 molecules and enhance oxidation activation capacity involved in the reaction process with increasing temperature. In-situ DRIFTS studies demonstrated that formate and carbonate species are the key intermediate species in CH4 combustion, and these species should be further oxidized by active oxygen species to the final products (i.e., CO2 and H2O). Owing to these favourable properties, we believe this catalyst can be considered as promising candidates and provide new opportunities for methane catalytic oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Exploring the state-of-the-art combustion catalysts that efficiently stabilize precious metal has been a wide concern to limit rising levels in methane emissions. Herein we exhibit that utilizing ultrathin mesoporous spinel catalysts (Co2MO4, M = Co, Mn, and Al) as a support can stabilize PdO cluster by strengthening the metal − support interactions at being close to atomic scale. These are found that the as-synthesized Pd-embedded catalysts possesses highly active surface lattice oxygen, enhanced Co3+ in the surface layers, and shows outstanding low-temperature reducibility. More importantly, in-situ XRD results reveals that Pd-Co2MnO4 is more sensitive to thermal effects than that of Co2MnO4, which leads to the surface phase migration of PdO clusters and lattice oxygen release on Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst. Among these catalysts, the Pd-Co2MnO4 catalyst performs the best catalytic activity for methane oxidation (T90 = 324 °C, Ea=37.4 kJ mol−1), especially with excellent cycle stability, and water-resistances. This study can be instructive for fabricating desirable heterogeneous catalysts and bring new insight into the design of highly efficient Pd-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Outstanding stability and highly efficient methane oxidation performance of palladium-embedded ultrathin mesoporous Co2MnO4 spinel catalyst
